GANG CHEN: OK, I wish you
all had a good weekend.

And just a recap
of last lecture--

it's a little bit extra
than last lecture-- but to say what we
solved is a problem

for heat conduction along a
two-dimensional, or thin, film.

And the Boltzmann equation,
reading for the deviation
function g, g is f minus f0.

So g is f minus f0. And we say g because the
boundary in the y direction,

so there are constraints
changing g in the y direction. So we have the cosine theta--

cosine theta is
the axial direction of the phonon propagation.

And so we have, on the left-hand
side is a function of y.

And then, on the right-hand
side, it's a function of x. The f0, because I
have f0 for phonon

is exponential
[INAUDIBLE] kt minus 1. So t is a function of x.

Because I would consider
heat conduction along the x direction.

And if you do electron
transport, which we didn't do last
time, you have to keep

this term, the fourth term. And that's one we
did in chapter 6, the thermoelectric transport.

We traded both terms. But see, the point
is if you look

at transport along
the x direction and on the right-hand side
is a function of x only.

So I have a first-order
differential equation for the deviation function
in the y direction

with right-hand
side is x dependent. So because of that, the right
hand is essentially constant.

Because the left-hand
side is a function of y. So when I did the integration,
I find the heat flux.

And what I'm given here is more
than I show in the last lecture

because this solution
is a Fuchs-Sondheimer--

Fuchs-Sond, I checked
the name, heimer--

solution.  and Fuchs-Sondheimer
originally solved

for the electron transport. So this were, in the original
paper, electric conductivity

ratio of the thin film divided
the bulk is, say, 1 minus.

So it's reduced. And this reduction is this
integral mu is cosine theta.

So it's 0 to 1. And the p is a
specularity parameter--

p specularity parameter. So if it's p equals
1, it's a specular.

P equals 0 is a diffuse. So you can say if the
specular 1 minus p is 0,

so it's more like a waveguide. There's no reduction if
it's a specular interface.

But the p equals 0 is diffuse,
so you will get reduction in the thermal conductivity,
or electric conductivity,

if the interface scattered
electron-phonon diffusely.

But say it has been,
actually, really difficult to say, what is this value of p?

And so far, the
best model people use was still result that
derived by Ziman in 1950s.

And this p is related
to the surface roughness and the wavelengths of
the phonon or electron.

So it's an exponential function. And in fact, you see in
the front it's 16 pi cubic.

So that's a pretty large number. Typically, in optics, when
people say a surface is rough,

or it's a specular, for
optically smooth surface, its typical roughness is less
than 1/10 of the wavelength.

So you can say if the
roughness is less than 1/10 of the wavelength, this
p is getting close to--

this one, when it's very
small, is close to 1.

That's specular. So this is a
Fuchs-Sondheimer solution.

And that's the for the
electrical and thermal

conductivity along a film. And then we assume that
the length of this film

is very long. So if you go to look
at the literature, there are a lot of
papers published

on measuring thermal
conductivity of thin films or nanowires.

And there are also
refined model of wires of different cross-section,
whether it's circular

or whether it is a rectangle. And the people have tried to
solve the Boltzmann equations.

And I mentioned that
in the last lecture, even now, there are still some
results on the wires, possibly,

and people still
writing what could be deviation from the Fuchs
and the Sondheimer solution.

And historically,
this is Casimir.

What Casimir did is,
really, he explained that

without solving
Boltzmann equation-- just no internal scattering,
you have rough surface--

and he say, OK, if you
have a rough surface because the scattering
is diffused, so you have,

effectively, reduction in the
mean free path of the heat carrier of the phonons.

And with that, he
was able to explain why thermal conductivity
at low temperature

is proportional
to specific heat. The mean free paths are
limited by the sample size and the low temperature.

[INAUDIBLE] the thermal
conductivity ones that are receiving gamma. So when the mean free
path is a sample size,

it is proportional
to the specific heat, which is t cubic.

So this is the Casimir
[INAUDIBLE] started. So that's last lecture is film
conduction along the film.

that recently, there are some paper on the thermal
conductivity of carbon

nanotubes. And it turns out that
because the thermal nanotube

or the mean free
path is even longer than the length of
the tube, so there is additional sizing factor
at the two ends of the tube.

And what are we going
